recommended_movies: The Bridge on the River Kwai (1957)

simulated_ratings.title: The Last of the Mohicans (1992)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Swept up by the rugged romance and frontier stakes, I felt that blend of history and heart I crave.

simulated_ratings.title: Unforgiven (1992)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Its moral reckoning and dusty melancholy hit me hard in the best Western way.

simulated_ratings.title: The Last Emperor (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The tragic arc and lavish history moved me, even if it kept me at a slight emotional distance.

simulated_ratings.title: A Man for All Seasons (1966)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Principled defiance and crisp dialogue scratched my itch for thoughtful historical drama.

simulated_ratings.title: Doctor Zhivago (1965)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The wartime sweep and aching romance resonated, though a touch long-winded for me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Bridge on the River Kwai (1957)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The tension between duty, pride, and sabotage was gripping and satisfying.

simulated_ratings.title: Ran (1985)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The grand betrayal and operatic battles impressed me more than they stirred me.

simulated_ratings.title: Seven Samurai (1954)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Honor, strategy, and community woven into an engrossing epic left me exhilarated.

simulated_ratings.title: The Mission (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Spiritual conviction colliding with colonial power was compelling, if a bit stately.

simulated_ratings.title: Beetlejuice (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Inventive and zany, fun in bursts but not quite my comedic sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: An American Werewolf in London (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The genre blend works well, giving me a smart, offbeat chill.

simulated_ratings.title: What We Do in the Shadows (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever and dry, amusing more than uproarious for my taste.

simulated_ratings.title: Pan's Labyrinth (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Its dark fairy-tale morality and wartime sorrow lingered with me.

simulated_ratings.title: Blade Runner (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody and thoughtful, but its cool detachment left me admiring more than loving.

simulated_ratings.title: Arrival (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet wonder and human stakes made the sci-fi feel intimate and worthwhile.

simulated_ratings.title: Her (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender, modern melancholy that intrigued me even if I was not fully swept away.

simulated_ratings.title: Children of Men (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Urgent, humane, and tense in a way that stuck with me.

simulated_ratings.title: Logan (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The weariness and grit deepened the genre, though I still kept some distance.

simulated_ratings.title: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (2000)

simulated_ratings.title: The Iron Giant (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest warmth and sacrifice gave me that satisfying lump in the throat.

simulated_ratings.title: The Incredibles (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever and energetic, enjoyable but not especially affecting for me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Princess Bride (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Charming and witty, cute more than transporting for me.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Refined feeling and restraint made the romance quietly rewarding.

simulated_ratings.title: The Remains of the Day (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Subtle heartbreak and duty over desire landed with a dignified ache.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Lively longing and social dance gave me a warm, contented glow.

simulated_ratings.title: Amadeus (1984)
